title: Asia's largest & oldest saw mill chatham
review_text:
It is not only holds the record of being Asia’s largest and oldest saw mill, but the history that Chatham Saw Mill had witnessed over the years makes it extraordinary from other mills. 
Chatham Saw Mill has been functioning as the backbone of the wood based industrial unit in the islands. 
The Department of Environment & Forests has established a modern Museum in the compound of Chatham Mill complex. 

As the museum exhibits almost all information about the history, geography, flora and fauna available in Andaman and Nicobar Islands, it is a storehouse of information on these islands for tourists.

title: A piece of "wooden" history !
review_text:
Chatham Saw mill is located on Chatham island , just off port Blair town connected by a bridge . There was a time not so long ago , there were many dozens of saw mills in Andamans and timber was a major industry by local standards . Obviously that resulted in indiscriminate deforestation and consequent environmental degradation . The Govt. Realized this folly and closed down all saw mills and brought a welcome stop to the felling of trees for timber . Chatham Saw mill is said to be the ONLY saw mill in the entire Andamans , run by the Govt , catering to the local needs of timber for construction and timber is a strictly regulated subject in Andamans. One can visit the mill ( at a nominal fee of a few rupees per pers) and watch the in action although some sections are out of bounds for public for safety reasons . title: Asia's largest and oldest Saw Mill
review_text:
Chatham Saw mill is located on Chatham island which is connected to Port Blair city through a bridge. This is Asia's largest and oldest saw mill. This was established during the British period to cater to the local timber needs for construction purpose. Later, timber from this mill was also exported overseas destinations. This mill was attacked by the Japanese during World War II. There is a bomb pit in the mill premises which was created by Japanese bombing. 

In Chatham Saw mill we get to see the entire process involved in obtaining wooden planks. Transport of logs to the saw mill on boats, storage in ware houses, sorting of logs, cutting them, making of wooden planks from the woods and transportation of these planks to the various usage points. All these process are shown by sign boards and there's proper explanation on these boards about each process. There is a forest museum as well which displays exhibits portraying fantastic work using Andaman woods. More

title: An Interesting Old Saw Mill
review_text:
I first visited Chatham Saw Mill back in 1998. At that time you wandered in, signed a visitor's book, and someone took you around the various workshops and storage units. A tip was given at the end of the tour and both parties were happy. 

Many years on and it has been turned into a tourist attraction of sorts. The layout is more or less the same and you are able to see where the tree trunks are delivered, seasoned and stored. You can also witness the process of sawing and sizing of the wood. No consideration is given to safety for the workers and indeed the visitor. A cursory wave of the hand by the workers to indicate where you should stand or move to for your own safety is all you will get. 

There is a museum with some nice carvings and displays giving information about the various woods and the geography of the Andaman Islands in general. There is also a shop where various wooden items can be purchased. 

I enjoyed my visit. More

title: Woods every were
review_text:
Chatham Saw Mill is one of Asia’s biggest and oldest saw mills. It was set up in 1883 by the British, now it is owned by the state government. The mill cuts huge, lofty logs of woods into usable wooden sticks. Here we see wood all around. Large piles of woods has been loaded, unloaded, sorted, cut and molded. Chatham Saw Mill produces sawn timber and handles the production of ‘Paduak’ – Andaman’s well known, premier wood. Earlier, locomotives were used to carry woods. Later, the use of locomotives was discarded. The pioneer giant has an installed capacity for sawing about 20,000 cum logs annually in three shifts. All the major timber trees of the Islands are used as raw material in the Mill. The entire production of sawn timber in the Mill is sold under the coverage of an Administered Price Mechanism and is consumed locally for furniture making, construction purposes. The export of timber from the Islands to the mainland is strictly prohibited. The Mill at present gives direct employment to about 750 persons. Working:- - The log depot segregates the logs received from the forests and feeds them into the Mill. - The mill section performs the conversion of round logs into various sizes. - The Timber Processing Unit carries out the seasoning and preservative treatment of sawn timber to increase its longevity. - Yard section handles the converted sawn timber as well as their sales. -... title: Wonderful visit
review_text:
My husband and I loved this place, which was part of our tour whilst in Port Blair. We love wood, so it made it a special place to see where it all happens. 

The museum is a great place to read up on the history and it houses many lovely photos of the time when the elephants were involved in the logging and transportation of the logs from Havelock Island. 

Although the directions of which way you should be going, are a bit hit and miss, it actually made it quite good fun, trying to work out where we went next. If you appreciate wood, you will love the different areas, where the wood has been categorised and graded. Nothing seems to be wasted, as even at the end of the process, the odd bits are sorted for the local craftsmen/market folk to take away. 

I was particularly impressed with the huge rollers that bring the logs from the water, into the saw mill, like a huge conveyer system. There was also a massive circular saw, the biggest I have ever seen. Be sure to stand next to it, to really appreciate it's size! 

A lovely way to spend an hour if you enjoy a bit of history More

title: Historical, Large, Working Timber Saw Mill
review_text:
The Government Saw Mill is located on Chatham Island which is linked by causeway to Port Blair. It is reachable from Port Blair by local bus or rickshaw, but is also walkable around the shore about 2 kilometers northwestwards from Phoenix Port. 
It is best to visit in the morning from about 9 am as there is strict entry control. A fee of 10 rupees is currently charged to enter. 
Within the gates one is free to wander around the saw mill, which is still working. The place where large logs are brought by sea and stored, the machinery used to cut them into planks, and the machinery to sharpen the large band saws used can all be seen in operation with explanations in English. 
There is also a small museum onsite run by the forestry department which contains some historical photographs, explanations about local varieties of wood, and some woodcraft exhibits. 
Chatham Island was one of the largest timber saw mills in SE Asia. It was set up by the British in 1883 for local requirements. It was bombed by the Japanese, and a large crater can still be seen behind the museum left by a Japanese bomb. It was also bombed by the British. But after World War II it was rebuilt and continued operations. 
There is a small stall to buy tea and coffee on site, but no restaurants on Chatham Island. More
